OVERVIEW: The Etoe series consists of deep, well drained soils that formed in alluvial-colluvial material from sandstone and shale. Etoe soils are on steep and very steep slopes. The mean annual precipitation is about 22 inches and the mean annual air temperature is about 41 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Ustic Palecryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Etoe loam, forested. (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
O1&O2--2 inches to 0; undecomposed and decomposed forest litter.
A21--0 to 3 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak, very fine granular structure; soft, friable, slightly plastic; many fine roots; many fine pores; less than 5 percent rock fragments; slightly acid; clear smooth boundary. (2 to 5 inches thick)
A22--3 to 11 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; single grained and weak very fine granular structure; soft, friable, slightly plastic; many few fine coarse and medium roots; many fine pores; less than 10 percent rock fragments; slightly acid; gradual wavy boundary. (6 to 10 inches thick)
A&B--11 to 24 inches; 85 percent (A) pale brown (10YR 6/3) cobbly loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; and 15 percent (B) strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) cobbly fine sandy loam, dry and moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable; many fine, few coarse and medium roots; many fine tubular pores; 25 percent rock fragments; slightly acid; gradual wavy boundary. (6 to 10 inches thick)
B&A--24 to 36 inches; 25 percent (B) strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) dry and moist, very cobbly fine sandy loam and 75 percent (A) pale brown (10YR 6/3) cobbly loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable; few coarse and medium roots; many fine tubular pores; 40 percent rock fragments; slightly acid; clear wavy boundary. (10 to 20 inches thick)
B21t--36 to 52 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) and dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) extremely cobbly sandy clay loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium subangular blocky and moderate fine granular structure; hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common fine roots; many fine pores; thick, patchy clay films; 60 percent rock fragments; neutral; clear wavy boundary. (12 to 20 inches thick)
B22t--52 to 73 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) and dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) extremely cobbly sandy clay loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium and fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine roots; many fine pores; thick patchy clay films; 70 percent rock fragments; neutral.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Colfax County, New Mexico; 12 miles south of Eagle Nest, one mile north-northwest of point where U. S. Highway 64 leaves the Morino Valley.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The annual soil temperature is 40 degrees to 46 degrees F., and the average summer soil temperature is 47 degrees to 50 degrees F. The solum is 60 to 90 inches thick. Depth to the argillic horizon ranges from 24 to 40 inches. Rock fragments are angular pebbles, cobbles, and stones of sandstone. Rock fragments in the A horizon range from 0 to 60 percent, in the mixed horizons from 20 to 65 percent, and in the B horizons from 50 to 85 percent. Some pedons have a thin A1 horizon.
The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3 dry and moist. It is loam, sandy loam or fine sandy loam.
The mixed horizons have hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 6 dry and moist. They are loam, sandy clay loam or fine sandy loam. These horizons have weak or moderate, medium or coarse subangular blocky structure.
The B2t horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 5YR, value of 3 through 7 dry and 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 6 dry and moist. It is heavy sandy loam, loam, or sandy clay loam and has 10 to 25 percent clay and more than 45 percent sand.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Angostura, Bundo, Coldcreek, Cundiyo, Gambler, Jorge, Lake Creek, Marosa, Tecolote, Tigeron and Yourame series. Angostura, Coldcreek, Cundiyo, Gambler, Jorge, Lake Creek, Tecolote and Yourame soils have argillic horizons whose upper boundary is shallower than 24 inches. Bundo soils have argillic horizons whose upper boundary is deeper than 45 inches. Marosa soils lack A&B and B&A horizons. Tigeron soils are strongly or medium acid.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Etoe soils are on steep and very steep, stony, convex northerly facing slopes at elevations of 9,000 to 11,000 feet.  The soils formed in colluvial-alluvial material from sandstone and shale of the Magdalena formation. The climate is continental. The average annual temperature is 38 degrees to 46 degrees F., and the average summer temperature is 45 degrees to 48 degrees F. The average annual precipitation is 18 to 25 inches, about 75 percent falling during the frost-free season. THe frost-free season is less than 90 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the competing Angostura soils and the Etown soils. Etown soils have a clayey-skeletal control section.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Timber production, wildlife, recreation and watershed. Overstory is Douglas-fir, white fir and aspen. Understory is shrubs and scattered mountain grasses.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern New Mexico and western Colorado.  This series is moderately extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Colfax County, New Mexico, 1974.

REMARKS.content:
ADDITIONAL DATA:  Lincoln Lab. S66NMex-4-1 (66L595).
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
